item.title: And so it begins
item.description:
Well, here it is: the first entry by a PIRE student in a PIRE location. Get the champagne ready--or in my case, the tapas y cerveza! I arrived in Granada, Spain 2 days ago to clear weather and friendly faces. Two graduate students in Teresa Bajo's lab, Luis Morales & Julia Morales (no relation), went to pick me up at the Granada airport which rivals our own University Park Airport in grandeur. After a short 10 minute drive, we arrived at the apartment that I'll be sharing with the other Granada PIRE students when they arrive later this year. The apartment is right in the heart of Granada near the cathedral. It was thanks to Luis & Julia that we were able to get such a great apartment.

In many ways, we truly lucked out with housing, which I want to make the focus of this post for the benefit of other PIRE students traveling soon. This part of PIRE travel preparations can be very time consuming, nerve-wracking, and certainly demands patience. Part of the frustration is that looking for housing from abroad is like trying to hammer a nail that you can't see using one of those extendo-claws. You have no idea what the apartment looks like; it's hard to estimate what neighborhood you should live in; and you are far away, making it difficult to contact owners and agencies. 

In part, differences are due to place. For example, Bangor, another PIRE site, is a smaller community but the research centre is accustomed to receiving many visitors, so the centre staff are incredible in helping one find housing, essentially booking a place for you as long as you provide advance notice. On the other hand, Granada is a mid-sized city with less support infrastructure for visitors, so more than likely PIRE visitors will have to figure out housing on their own. In addition, Spain in general relies more upon interactions and queries made through phone and not as much through internet or e-mail.

Not to fret, it is not impossible to find temporary housing abroad! Below the fold are some suggestions for making the search perhaps a tad bit easier.

item.title: PIRE Partners in the News: VL2 and Memory and Language Research Group
item.description:
Two recent press releases highlight the collaborations with PIRE partners. One is the recent TV show featuring Teresa Bajo's lab. The segment, linked here, is all in Spanish and the work by Teresa's group starts at around 9:30--you'll definitely see some friendly faces. If you head to around 13:00 and you'll see our very own visual world experiment being demonstrated and pay close attention and you'll hear Rosa Guzzardo's voice--recorded for life on this news segment!

The other segment, linked here, is on the work with Jill Morford and VL2. This was issued as a press release from Penn State but has been picked up in many places, including US News and World Reports.

item.title: PIRE Week: From the 'Photogropher's' Perspective
item.description:
Last week, the Center for Language Science welcomed its colleagues
from across the world to participate in a series of talks and events
to inaugurate the PIRE collaborations. From my perspective as a
research technologist, this past week was not only an opportunity to
learn about the research that our partners are conducting at their
respective institutions but also an opportunity for intellectual
growth and a chance to receive feedback on my current project. Sitting
down with an international collaborator on my project and having a
one-on-one conversation proved to be an invaluable experience because
I realized just how much this research advances our understanding of
what it means to be bilingual. Throughout the week, our PIRE
undergraduate and graduate students met with researchers from the
partner universities and had the chance to hear more about what they
are going to experience when they visit the research sites this
summer.

In addition to the talks and personal meetings, I had the opportunity
to present the research that I am currently conducting at a lab
meeting and the student poster session. It is only normal to feel
slightly intimidated by the idea of talking in front of a group of
internationally recognized and distinguished researchers, but it's
important to realize that they are interested in our research and
ability to think critically about the consequences that our work will
have for the research community. In addition to explaining my research
to our partners and fellow students, I also gained valuable feedback
on the design and potential outcomes of the study.

item.title: CLS-PIRE website launches for conference
item.description:
The Center for Language Science's PIRE website has been officially launched at the PIRE Science meeting today. The website is publicly available at: http://cls.psu.edu/pire.

PIRE Co-PI Ping Li offered these remarks:

The PIRE website serves as a gateway for bringing together domestic and international researchers and students interested in the study of bilingualism, language acquisition, second language learning from the perspectives of linguistics, cognitive psychology, and cognitive neuroscience.   Funded by the National Science Foundation, the PIRE project highlights international collaboration, student engagement, and cross-disciplinary inquiry.
